content: Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure at sea level. This temperature varies with elevation due to changes in atmospheric pressure.
The Earth's average surface temperature has increased by approximately 1.1°C since pre-industrial times due to greenhouse gas emissions from human activities.
Climate change is primarily caused by anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. The IPCC has concluded with high confidence that human influence is the dominant cause of observed warming.
The Great Wall of China is not visible from space with the naked eye. NASA astronauts have confirmed this myth is false.
The Earth is an oblate spheroid, slightly flattened at the poles. Satellite imagery, physics, and navigation systems confirm this shape.
Lightning frequently strikes the same location multiple times. The Empire State Building is struck 20-25 times per year.
The human body contains approximately 37.2 trillion cells according to a 2013 study, including 30 trillion red blood cells.
The Amazon rainforest produces 6-9% of world oxygen, not 20%. Ocean phytoplankton produce about 50%.
Goldfish have memory lasting months, not three seconds. They can be trained to recognize shapes, colors, and sounds.
Humans use virtually all of their brain, not just 10%. fMRI imaging confirms all brain regions are active almost constantly.
Glass is an amorphous solid, not a slow-flowing liquid. Old window thickness variations resulted from manufacturing.
Humans can only see visible light (380-700nm), not ultraviolet light (10-380nm). The eye filters out UV radiation.
Honey never spoils when properly stored. Its low moisture and high acidity prevent bacterial growth. 3000-year-old honey has been found edible.
Microwaves use non-ionizing radiation and do not make food radioactive. The FDA confirms microwaved food remains non-radioactive.
Evolution by natural selection is supported by fossils, genetics, comparative anatomy, and observed speciation events.
Humans and chimpanzees share 98-99% DNA similarity, evidence for common evolutionary ancestry.
Antarctica is 98% covered by ice. The remaining 2% consists of exposed rock outcrops and ice-free valleys.
The Dead Sea surface at 1,410 feet below sea level is Earth's lowest land point. The Mariana Trench is deeper but underwater.
The speed of light in vacuum is exactly 299,792,458 m/s. This is a fundamental constant in Einstein's relativity.
Einstein published special relativity in 1905 and general relativity in 1915, revolutionizing physics.
DNA's double helix structure was discovered by Watson and Crick in 1953, building on Rosalind Franklin's X-ray work.
The Sun is 93 million miles from Earth. Light takes 8 minutes 20 seconds to reach Earth.
Mars has been visited only by robotic rovers, not humans. No crewed missions to Mars have been completed as of 2025.
The 1969 Moon landing was real. Evidence includes lunar samples, retroreflectors, and independent international verification.
The solar system has eight planets. Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 by the IAU.
Gravity gives weight to objects and causes them to fall. Earth's surface gravity is approximately 9.8 m/s².
The periodic table organizes 118 confirmed chemical elements by atomic structure. Mendeleev published the first in 1869.
The Big Bang occurred approximately 13.8 billion years ago. Evidence includes cosmic microwave background radiation.
Black holes are regions where gravity prevents light from escaping. The first image was captured by Event Horizon Telescope in 2019.
Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy. Plants use CO2, water, and sunlight to produce glucose and oxygen.
Plate tectonics explains Earth's lithosphere movement. Plates move due to mantle convection, causing earthquakes and mountains.
Atoms consist of a nucleus with protons and neutrons, surrounded by electrons in orbital shells.
The Bermuda Triangle has no more disappearances than other ocean areas of similar size. Insurance data shows no unusual risk.
Dinosaurs became extinct 66 million years ago, likely from an asteroid impact causing catastrophic climate change.
The water cycle includes evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and runoff, distributing water across the planet.
Newton's three laws of motion form classical mechanics: inertia, F=ma, and action-reaction.
Quantum mechanics deals with atomic and subatomic behavior, including wave-particle duality and uncertainty principle.
The Hubble Space Telescope launched in 1990 has made over 1.5 million observations, revolutionizing astronomy.
The human genome contains 3 billion DNA base pairs and 20,000-25,000 genes. The Human Genome Project completed in 2003.
Darwin published 'Origin of Species' in 1859, introducing evolution by natural selection.
The ozone layer absorbs UV radiation. The Montreal Protocol (1987) reduced ozone-depleting CFCs. The ozone hole is recovering.
Stem cells can develop into specialized cell types, with applications in regenerative medicine.
The Higgs boson was discovered at CERN in 2012, confirming the Standard Model of particle physics.
Climate models predict 1.5-4°C temperature rise by 2100 depending on emission scenarios.
Metamorphosis involves dramatic physical transformation. Butterflies undergo complete metamorphosis with four life stages.
The human heart pumps 2,000 gallons of blood daily, beating 100,000 times per day.
Earthquakes occur when tectonic plates release accumulated stress. Magnitude is measured using Richter or moment magnitude scales.
Volcanoes form when magma reaches Earth's surface. The Ring of Fire contains 75% of active volcanoes.
The Milky Way contains 100-400 billion stars and has a diameter of 100,000 light-years.
Antibiotics fight bacterial infections but are ineffective against viruses. Overuse contributes to antibiotic resistance.
Continental drift, proposed by Wegener in 1912, was later incorporated into plate tectonics theory.
Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass. Solar and wind costs have decreased dramatically.
Nuclear fission splits atomic nuclei to release energy. Nuclear power produces no carbon emissions but creates radioactive waste.
The ISS has been continuously occupied since November 2000, orbiting at 250 miles altitude.
CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing allows precise DNA modifications. Discovered in 2012, it has medical and agricultural applications.
COVID-19 vaccines significantly reduce severe illness, hospitalization, and death. Clinical trials and real-world data demonstrate efficacy.
COVID-19 vaccines don't contain fetal cells. Some used fetal cell lines in research, but final products contain only proteins and lipids.
Vaccines don't contain microchips or tracking devices. Vaccine ingredients are publicly listed and verified.
Vitamin C doesn't cure the common cold, though it may slightly reduce symptom duration by about 8%.
Humans use virtually all of their brain. Brain imaging shows most regions are active constantly, even during sleep.
Water fluoridation reduces dental caries by 25% in children and 15% in adults. WHO endorses it as safe and effective.
Mobile phones don't cause brain cancer. The INTERPHONE study found no conclusive link. WHO classifies RF as possibly carcinogenic (Group 2B) but evidence is weak.
Antibiotics only work against bacteria, not viruses. Taking them for viral infections contributes to antibiotic resistance.
The US has the highest per capita healthcare spending at $11,945 annually, exceeding Switzerland ($9,673) and Germany ($8,176).
Sugar doesn't cause hyperactivity in children. Multiple controlled studies found no direct link. The myth persists due to expectancy bias.
Cracking knuckles doesn't cause arthritis. The popping sound is from gas bubbles in synovial fluid, not joint damage.
Reading in dim light doesn't permanently damage eyesight. It may cause temporary eye strain but no lasting harm.
Shaving doesn't make hair grow back thicker. Hair appears thicker because blunt edges feel coarser than natural tapered tips.
Moderate alcohol doesn't directly kill brain cells in healthy adults. Excessive drinking can damage brain tissue through various mechanisms.
The human body is approximately 60% water. Water is essential for temperature regulation, nutrient transport, and waste removal.
Vaccines don't cause autism. This fraudulent claim has been thoroughly debunked. Extensive research found no link.
Humans have five main senses plus proprioception, equilibrioception, thermoception, and nociception.
Hand washing with soap for 20 seconds effectively prevents infection spread. Wash before eating and after using restroom.
Exercise provides cardiovascular fitness, weight management, improved mental health, and reduced chronic disease risk. WHO recommends 150 minutes weekly.
Adults need 7-9 hours of sleep nightly. Chronic sleep deprivation increases obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease risk.
Smoking is the leading cause of preventable death, causing cancer, heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Quitting at any age provides benefits.
The Mediterranean diet reduces heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, and certain cancers. It emphasizes plant-based foods and healthy fats.
BMI is weight (kg) divided by height (m) squared. It's useful for populations but doesn't distinguish muscle from fat.
Mental health is as important as physical health. Depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia are treatable conditions.
Type 2 diabetes affects blood sugar regulation. Risk factors include obesity and inactivity. Often preventable through lifestyle changes.
High blood pressure (hypertension) often has no symptoms. It increases heart attack, stroke, and kidney disease risk. Normal is below 120/80.
Breast cancer is most common in women worldwide. Early detection through mammography improves survival. Treatment includes surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
Probiotics are live microorganisms providing health benefits. Found in yogurt, kefir, and sauerkraut. May help digestive and immune health.
Sunscreen protects from UV radiation causing sunburn, aging, and skin cancer. Use SPF 30+ broad-spectrum, reapply every 2 hours.
The immune system protects from pathogens including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites. Includes innate and adaptive responses.
LDL ('bad') cholesterol builds up in arteries. HDL ('good') cholesterol removes cholesterol. Diet and medication manage levels.
Osteoporosis causes weak, brittle bones. Primarily affects older adults, especially postmenopausal women. Prevention includes calcium and vitamin D.
Asthma causes airway inflammation and breathing difficulties. Triggers include allergens, exercise, and cold air. Treatment involves bronchodilators and corticosteroids.
Alzheimer's disease is the most common dementia, affecting memory and thinking. It's progressive with no cure. Risk increases with age.
The placebo effect demonstrates mind-body connection. Patients may improve from inactive treatments due to expectations.
Anesthesia allows painless surgery. General anesthesia causes unconsciousness; local numbs specific areas. Modern anesthesia is very safe.
Blood types are ABO (A, B, AB, O) and Rh (+ or -). Type O negative is universal donor; AB positive is universal recipient.
One organ donor can save up to eight lives. Organs include heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, pancreas, and intestines.
The digestive system breaks down food into absorbable nutrients. Includes mouth, esophagus, stomach, intestines, liver, and pancreas. Takes 24-72 hours.
Chronic stress negatively impacts health, causing headaches, high blood pressure, and anxiety. Management includes exercise, meditation, and sleep.
Hormones regulate metabolism, growth, mood, and reproduction. Major hormones include insulin, thyroid hormones, cortisol, estrogen, and testosterone.
The skeletal system has 206 bones in adults. It provides structure, protects organs, anchors muscles, and stores minerals.
CPR maintains circulation during cardiac arrest. Involves chest compressions and rescue breaths. Prompt CPR doubles or triples survival chances.
Kidney disease develops slowly with few early symptoms. Kidneys filter waste from blood. Risk factors include diabetes and high blood pressure.
Pregnancy lasts approximately 40 weeks in three trimesters. Prenatal care is essential. Important factors include nutrition and avoiding alcohol/tobacco.
The Eiffel Tower was completed in March 1889 for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris. It was designed by Gustave Eiffel and stands 330 meters tall.
The Titanic sank on April 15, 1912, after hitting an iceberg on its maiden voyage. It rests at 12,500 feet depth in the North Atlantic.
World War II lasted from 1939 to 1945. It involved most nations and resulted in 70-85 million fatalities, making it the deadliest conflict in history.
The Great Wall of China was built over centuries, primarily during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644). It stretches over 13,000 miles.
The American Declaration of Independence was adopted on July 4, 1776, declaring independence from Great Britain.
The Great Tokyo Earthquake (Kantō earthquake) struck on September 1, 1923. It killed over 140,000 people and destroyed much of Tokyo and Yokohama.
The Mona Lisa was painted by Leonardo da Vinci between 1503 and 1519 during the Italian Renaissance. It's displayed in the Louvre Museum.
The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, marking the end of the Cold War era. It had divided East and West Berlin since 1961.
The French Revolution began in 1789 and led to the end of the monarchy, the rise of Napoleon, and profound changes in European politics.
The Roman Empire lasted from 27 BC to 476 AD in the West and until 1453 AD in the East. It profoundly influenced Western civilization.
Christopher Columbus reached the Americas in 1492, though Vikings had visited centuries earlier. His voyages initiated European colonization.
The printing press was invented by Johannes Gutenberg around 1440. It revolutionized information spread and contributed to the Renaissance.
The American Civil War (1861-1865) was fought between the Union and Confederate states over slavery and states' rights. About 620,000 soldiers died.
The Magna Carta was sealed in 1215, establishing the principle that the monarch is subject to law. It influenced constitutional development worldwide.
The Industrial Revolution began in Britain in the late 18th century, transforming economies from agrarian to industrial.
The Ancient Egyptian civilization lasted from approximately 3100 BC to 30 BC. It's known for pyramids, pharaohs, and hieroglyphics.
The Renaissance was a cultural movement from the 14th to 17th century, beginning in Italy. It saw renewed interest in classical learning and art.
The Holocaust during WWII resulted in the genocide of six million Jews and millions of others by Nazi Germany.
The Silk Road was an ancient network of trade routes connecting East and West from the 2nd century BC to the 15th century AD.
The Spanish flu pandemic of 1918-1919 infected 500 million people worldwide (one-third of the population) and killed 50-100 million.
The moon landing on July 20, 1969, saw Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin become the first humans to walk on the Moon during Apollo 11.
The Reformation began in 1517 when Martin Luther posted his 95 Theses, challenging Catholic Church practices and leading to Protestantism.
The Russian Revolution of 1917 overthrew the Tsarist autocracy and led to the establishment of the Soviet Union.
The Age of Exploration (15th-17th centuries) saw European explorers discovering new trade routes and lands, including the Americas and routes to Asia.
The Great Depression began with the 1929 stock market crash and lasted through the 1930s, causing widespread unemployment and economic hardship.
Ancient Greece (800 BC - 146 BC) gave birth to democracy, philosophy, drama, and the Olympic Games. Athens and Sparta were major city-states.
The Black Death (bubonic plague) pandemic of 1347-1353 killed 75-200 million people in Eurasia and North Africa, about 30-60% of Europe's population.
The Code of Hammurabi from ancient Babylon (circa 1754 BC) is one of the oldest written legal codes, featuring 282 laws.
The Crusades were religious wars between 1096 and 1291, primarily between Christians and Muslims over control of the Holy Land.
The Qing Dynasty ruled China from 1644 to 1912, the last imperial dynasty. It ended with the Xinhai Revolution.
The Treaty of Versailles ended WWI in 1919. Its harsh terms on Germany contributed to WWII. It created the League of Nations.
The Maya civilization flourished in Mesoamerica from 2000 BC to 1500 AD, known for architecture, mathematics, astronomy, and writing.
The Boston Tea Party (December 16, 1773) was a protest against British taxation. Colonists dumped 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor.
The fall of Constantinople in 1453 to the Ottoman Empire marked the end of the Byzantine Empire and is considered the end of the Middle Ages.
The Scramble for Africa (1881-1914) saw European powers colonize and partition Africa, with lasting impacts on the continent.
The Napoleonic Wars (1803-1815) reshaped Europe. Napoleon's military campaigns spread revolutionary ideals but ended with his defeat at Waterloo.
The Aztec Empire (1428-1521) in central Mexico was conquered by Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés. It was known for architecture and advanced society.
The Viking Age (793-1066 AD) saw Scandinavian seafarers explore, raid, and trade across Europe, reaching North America around 1000 AD.
The Hundred Years' War (1337-1453) between England and France shaped both nations. Joan of Arc was a key figure.
The Mongol Empire (1206-1368) was the largest contiguous land empire in history, founded by Genghis Khan.
The partition of India in 1947 created independent India and Pakistan, accompanied by mass migration and violence killing up to 2 million.
The Cuban Missile Crisis (October 1962) brought the US and USSR closest to nuclear war during the Cold War.
The fall of the Roman Empire in 476 AD marked the end of ancient Rome. Multiple factors including invasions and economic troubles contributed.
The Watergate scandal (1972-1974) led to President Nixon's resignation. It involved illegal activities including break-ins and cover-ups.
The Women's Suffrage Movement fought for women's voting rights. The 19th Amendment gave US women the vote in 1920.
The Ottoman Empire (1299-1922) was a major power controlling southeastern Europe, western Asia, and northern Africa.
The Battle of Hastings (1066) saw Norman conquest of England. William the Conqueror defeated King Harold II.
The Persian Empire (550-330 BC) under Cyrus the Great was the world's first superpower, spanning three continents.
The Meiji Restoration (1868) transformed Japan from a feudal society to a modern industrialized nation in just decades.
The Wars of the Roses (1455-1487) were English civil wars between Houses of Lancaster and York. They ended with Henry Tudor's victory.
The Louisiana Purchase (1803) doubled US territory. America bought 828,000 square miles from France for $15 million.
The Irish Potato Famine (1845-1852) killed about 1 million and caused 1 million to emigrate. It profoundly affected Irish history.
Nelson Mandela fought against apartheid in South Africa. He was imprisoned 27 years, then became president (1994-1999).
The Suez Crisis (1956) involved Egypt, Israel, UK, and France. It marked the end of British and French dominance in the Middle East.
The invention of gunpowder in 9th century China revolutionized warfare. It spread to Europe by the 13th century.
Python programming language was created by Guido van Rossum. First released in 1991, it emphasizes code readability and simplicity.
The Internet originated from ARPANET in the late 1960s. TCP/IP protocols were adopted in 1983, and the World Wide Web was invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989.
Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web (WWW) in 1989 while working at CERN. He created HTTP, HTML, and the first web browser.
Smartphones use significantly more electricity than traditional phones due to processing power, large displays, and wireless connectivity.
The first transatlantic telegraph cable was successfully laid in 1858, connecting Ireland and Newfoundland. It revolutionized international communication.
Artificial intelligence can pass the Turing Test. Modern language models can successfully fool evaluators in conversational scenarios.
The transistor was invented at Bell Labs in 1947. It revolutionized electronics and led to modern computing.
The first electronic computer, ENIAC, was completed in 1945. It weighed 30 tons and occupied 1,800 square feet.
The microprocessor, invented by Intel in 1971, integrated all CPU functions onto a single chip, enabling personal computers.
Email was invented by Ray Tomlinson in 1971. He sent the first network email and chose the @ symbol for addresses.
GPS (Global Positioning System) was developed by the US military and made available for civilian use in 1983. It uses 24+ satellites.
The first iPhone was released by Apple in 2007, revolutionizing mobile phones by combining phone, internet, and music player.
Blockchain technology underlies cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. It provides a decentralized, secure ledger for transactions.
Cloud computing delivers computing services over the internet. Major providers include AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud.
Machine learning is a subset of AI where computers learn from data without explicit programming. Applications include image recognition and natural language processing.
Fiber optic cables transmit data as light pulses through glass fibers. They enable high-speed internet with speeds up to terabits per second.
Quantum computing uses quantum bits (qubits) that can exist in multiple states simultaneously. It promises to solve problems intractable for classical computers.
The Ethernet networking standard was developed by Robert Metcalfe at Xerox PARC in 1973. It remains the dominant LAN technology.
USB (Universal Serial Bus) was introduced in 1996 to standardize computer peripherals. USB-C is the latest standard supporting high-speed data and power.
Virtual reality (VR) creates immersive digital environments. Modern VR headsets provide realistic graphics and motion tracking for gaming and training.
3D printing (additive manufacturing) builds objects layer by layer from digital models. Applications span prototyping, manufacturing, and medicine.
Autonomous vehicles use sensors, cameras, and AI to navigate without human control. Major companies are developing self-driving car technology.
The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) develops web standards including HTML, CSS, and XML to ensure interoperability.
Open source software has publicly available source code. Linux, Apache, and Firefox are prominent examples. It promotes collaboration and transparency.
Encryption protects data by encoding it so only authorized parties can access it. Modern encryption uses complex mathematical algorithms.
The Internet of Things (IoT) connects everyday devices to the internet. Applications include smart homes, wearables, and industrial sensors.
Solid-state drives (SSDs) use flash memory instead of spinning disks. They're faster, more durable, and energy-efficient than hard disk drives.
5G networks provide faster speeds, lower latency, and support more connected devices than 4G. Deployment began globally around 2019.
Linux is an open-source operating system kernel created by Linus Torvalds in 1991. It powers most servers and Android devices.
Biometric authentication uses unique physical characteristics like fingerprints, facial recognition, or iris scans for security.
Augmented reality (AR) overlays digital information onto the real world. Applications include mobile games, navigation, and industrial training.
The Raspberry Pi is a low-cost single-board computer launched in 2012. It's used for education, prototyping, and DIY projects.
Git is a distributed version control system created by Linus Torvalds in 2005. GitHub and GitLab are popular hosting platforms.
Docker containers package software with dependencies for consistent deployment across environments. It revolutionized application deployment.
Natural language processing (NLP) enables computers to understand and generate human language. Applications include chatbots and translation.
Wi-Fi provides wireless local area networking based on IEEE 802.11 standards. Wi-Fi 6 is the latest generation offering improved speed and capacity.
Cryptocurrency is digital currency using cryptography for security. Bitcoin, created in 2009, was the first decentralized cryptocurrency.
API (Application Programming Interface) allows different software applications to communicate. RESTful APIs are common for web services.
Serverless computing allows developers to build applications without managing servers. Cloud providers handle infrastructure automatically.
Edge computing processes data near the source rather than in centralized data centers, reducing latency for IoT and real-time applications.
Big data refers to extremely large datasets analyzed computationally to reveal patterns and trends. Technologies include Hadoop and Spark.
DevOps combines software development and IT operations to shorten development cycles and provide continuous delivery.
Kubernetes is an open-source container orchestration platform for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
Microservices architecture structures applications as collections of loosely coupled services, improving modularity and scalability.
Deep learning uses neural networks with multiple layers to learn from data. It powers image recognition, speech recognition, and autonomous vehicles.
Donald Trump was elected the 45th US President in 2016, defeating Hillary Clinton. He served from 2017 to 2021.
Joe Biden is the 46th President of the United States. He was inaugurated on January 20, 2021, after defeating Donald Trump in 2020.
The United States Electoral College system has 538 electors. A candidate needs 270 electoral votes to win the presidency.
The United Nations was founded in 1945 after WWII. It has 193 member states and aims to maintain international peace and security.
The European Union was established by the Maastricht Treaty in 1993. It has 27 member states after the UK's departure (Brexit) in 2020.
The US Constitution was ratified in 1788. It established the framework of the US government with three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.
The US Supreme Court has nine justices appointed for life. It's the highest judicial authority in the United States.
NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization) was founded in 1949 as a military alliance. It has 31 member countries as of 2023.
The UN Security Council has 15 members, including 5 permanent members (US, UK, France, Russia, China) with veto power.
The Watergate scandal led to President Richard Nixon's resignation in 1974. It involved break-ins and cover-ups of illegal activities.
The Civil Rights Act of 1964 outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin in the United States.
The Voting Rights Act of 1965 prohibited racial discrimination in voting, particularly affecting Southern states.
The Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) was signed into law in 2010, expanding health insurance coverage to millions of Americans.
The US Congress consists of two chambers: the Senate (100 members) and the House of Representatives (435 members).
Impeachment is the process by which a legislature brings charges against a government official. The House impeaches; the Senate tries the case.
The 22nd Amendment limits US presidents to two terms in office. It was ratified in 1951 after Franklin Roosevelt's four terms.
The US federal government operates on a system of checks and balances among executive, legislative, and judicial branches.
Parliamentary systems feature a prime minister as head of government, chosen by the legislature. Examples include the UK, Canada, and India.
The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted by the UN in 1948. It outlines fundamental human rights to be universally protected.
Lobbying involves attempting to influence government decisions. Lobbyists represent various interests including corporations, unions, and advocacy groups.
Gerrymandering is the manipulation of electoral district boundaries to favor one party. It's a controversial practice affecting fair representation.
The separation of powers divides government into distinct branches with separate functions to prevent concentration of power.
A filibuster is a tactic used in the US Senate to delay or block legislative action by extending debate indefinitely.
The G7 is a group of seven major advanced economies: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, UK, and US. They meet annually to discuss global issues.
Term limits restrict the number of terms an elected official can serve. The US president is limited to two terms; many state governors have term limits.
Mount Everest is the world's highest mountain at 8,849 meters (29,032 feet) above sea level, located in the Himalayas on the Nepal-China border.
The Amazon River is the world's largest river by discharge volume and the second longest after the Nile. It flows through South America.
The Sahara Desert is the world's largest hot desert, covering 9 million square kilometers across North Africa.
Russia is the world's largest country by land area at 17.1 million km². It spans 11 time zones across Europe and Asia.
The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean, covering more than 63 million square miles (165 million km²).
The Mariana Trench is the deepest point in Earth's oceans at approximately 36,000 feet (11,000 meters) below sea level.
The Nile River is traditionally considered the world's longest river at approximately 6,650 km (4,130 miles), flowing through northeastern Africa.
Antarctica is the world's fifth-largest continent and the coldest, driest, and windiest. It contains 70% of Earth's fresh water as ice.
The Grand Canyon in Arizona is 277 miles long, up to 18 miles wide, and over 1 mile deep. It was carved by the Colorado River.
The Great Barrier Reef off Australia's coast is the world's largest coral reef system, stretching over 2,300 kilometers.
The Ring of Fire is a major area in the Pacific Ocean basin where many earthquakes and volcanic eruptions occur, containing 75% of active volcanoes.
The Dead Sea between Israel and Jordan is Earth's lowest land elevation at 430 meters below sea level. It's one of the saltiest bodies of water.
Vatican City is the world's smallest country at 0.17 square miles (0.44 km²), located within Rome, Italy.
China is the world's most populous country with over 1.4 billion people, followed by India with a similar population.
The Himalayas are the world's highest mountain range, formed by the collision of Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates.
Australia is both a country and a continent, the world's sixth-largest country by total area at 7.7 million km².
The Mediterranean Sea connects to the Atlantic Ocean through the Strait of Gibraltar. It borders 21 countries across three continents.
The Andes are the world's longest continental mountain range, extending 7,000 km along South America's western coast.
Lake Baikal in Siberia is the world's deepest and oldest freshwater lake, containing 20% of the world's unfrozen freshwater.
The equator divides Earth into Northern and Southern Hemispheres. It passes through 13 countries with a length of 40,075 km.
Greenland is the world's largest island at 2.16 million km², located between the Arctic and Atlantic Oceans. Most of it is covered by ice.
The Congo River is the world's deepest river and Africa's second-longest. It's the only major river crossing the equator twice.
Tokyo is the world's most populous metropolitan area with over 37 million people in the greater Tokyo area.
The Alps are Europe's highest and most extensive mountain range, stretching across eight countries with 82 peaks above 4,000 meters.
The Panama Canal connects the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans through the Isthmus of Panama. It opened in 1914 and revolutionized maritime trade.
